description: From Latin suffocatus, past participle of suffocare (“to choke, stifle”), from sub (“under”) + faux (“the upper part of the throat, the pharynx”).

adjectives.description: suffocate (comparative more suffocate, superlative most suffocate)

verbs.description: suffocate (third-person singular simple present suffocates, present participle suffocating, simple past and past participle suffocated)

entries.meaning: (ergative) To suffer, or cause someone to suffer, from severely reduced oxygen intake to the body.
examples: Open the hatch, he is suffocating in the airlock!

entries.meaning: (ergative) To die due to, or kill someone by means of, insufficient oxygen supply to the body.
examples: He suffocated his wife by holding a pillow over her head.

entries.meaning: (ergative, figuratively) To overwhelm, or be overwhelmed (by a person or issue), as though with oxygen deprivation.
examples: I'm suffocating under this huge workload.
